questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of a 3-day history of a runny nose, headache, and cough. The patient's grandson recently had similar symptoms. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Testing of nasal secretions is performed to identify the viral strain. Electron microscopy shows a non-enveloped RNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. Binding to which of the following is responsible for the virulence of this virus?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

P antigens, which are blood group antigens found on human erythrocytes, are used by parvovirus B19 to infect erythroid progenitor cells. Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped virus that can be transmitted by respiratory droplets. However, it is a DNA virus and it typically causes anemia (due to red cell aplasia) and self-limiting arthritis in adults, unlike this patient with a runny nose, headache, and cough.

B) INCORRECT:

CD21, which is a complement receptor present in mature B lymphocytes, is used by EBV to cause infection. EBV has an icosahedral capsid, can be transmitted by droplets, and can cause a headache as well as a runny nose. However, EBV is an enveloped DNA virus, and additional symptoms such as a sore throat, fever, fatigue, and cervical lymphadenopathy (infectious mononucleosis) would be expected in acute EBV infection. Rhinovirus does not bind to CD21.

C) INCORRECT:

CCR5 (CD195) is a WBC receptor that is essential for infection by HIV. HIV is an RNA virus. However, it is enveloped and it has a capsid with a complex, conical shape. Moreover, HIV spreads through sexual contact, infected needle sticks, or blood transfusion, and acute HIV infection typically causes fever, myalgia, sore throat, lymphadenopathy and/or a rash; a runny nose and cough are not typical features of acute HIV infection. Rhinovirus does not bind to CCR5.

D) CORRECT:

Rhinovirus binds to ICAM-1 (CD54) expressed on respiratory epithelial cells. Infected epithelial cells release inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-1 (IL-1) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), which lead to clinical symptoms and induce further expression of ICAM-1 molecules, helping viral progeny to infect neighboring cells.

See “Receptors used by viruses” table.

E) INCORRECT:

CXCR4 is a coreceptor in lymphocytes that binds to SDF-1 and plays a central role in infection by some HIV serotypes. HIV is an RNA virus. However, it is enveloped and it has a capsid with a complex, conical shape. Moreover, HIV spreads through sexual contact, infected needle sticks, or blood transfusion, and acute HIV infection typically causes fever, myalgia, sore throat, lymphadenopathy and/or a rash; a runny nose and cough are not typical features of acute HIV infection. Rhinovirus does not bind to CXCR4.

F) INCORRECT:

Sialic acid residues are used by influenza viruses (orthomyxoviruses), adenoviruses, and rotaviruses to cause infection. Influenza viruses are RNA viruses that often affect elderly patients and can cause a runny nose, headache, and cough. However, they are enveloped and have a helical capsid. Adenoviruses are non-enveloped viruses that can cause a headache, runny nose, and cough but they are DNA viruses. Rotaviruses are non-enveloped RNA viruses with an icosahedral capsid but they cause severe diarrhea in children; they do not cause a cough, runny nose, and headache.

G) INCORRECT:

Integrins are used as entry receptors by the cytomegalovirus (CMV), which has an icosahedral capsid, can be transmitted by droplets, and can cause a headache as well as a runny nose. However, CMV is an enveloped DNA virus, and additional symptoms such as a sore throat, fever, and cervical lymphadenopathy (mononucleosis-like illness) would be expected in acute CMV infection in immunocompetent patients. A cough can occur in immunocompromised patients due to CMV pneumonia but CMV pneumonia typically does not occur in immunocompetent patients. Rhinovirus binds to a surface glycoprotein that binds to certain types of integrins but rhinovirus itself does not bind to any integrins.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are consistent with the common cold. Rhinovirus is a non-enveloped RNA virus with an icosahedral capsid and the most common cause of the common cold.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of several bumps on his fingers. He has no history of serious illness and is up-to-date on all immunizations. Physical examination shows several superficial, flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules along the dorsal aspect of the fingers with minimal surrounding hyperpigmentation. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. A virus with which of the following characteristics is most likely responsible for this patient's findings?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arenaviruses and bunyaviruses are enveloped RNA viruses with a segmented circular, single-stranded genome, and helical capsid shape. They are responsible for a variety of acute febrile illnesses such as Lassa fever and Hantavirus syndromes that manifest with cutaneous symptoms, including rash. However, neither arenaviruses nor bunyaviruses would cause superficial, flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules in an otherwise healthy pediatric patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthomyxoviruses, paramyxoviruses, rhabdoviruses, filoviruses, and coronaviruses are all enveloped RNA viruses with a linear, single-stranded genome and helical capsid shape. Cutaneous manifestations of viruses in these families include the erythematous maculopapular rashes caused by the measles virus (a paramyxovirus) and hemorrhagic fever caused by the Ebola and Marburg viruses (filoviruses). However, none of these viruses would cause superficial, flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules in an otherwise healthy pediatric patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Poxviruses are enveloped DNA viruses with a linear, double-stranded genome and complex capsid shape. Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus. It is most frequently seen in children and presents with flesh-colored papules, as seen here. However, the lesions of molluscum contagiosum are pearly, dome-shaped and have a central umbilication, unlike the lesions described in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpesviruses are enveloped DNA viruses with a linear, double-stranded genome and icosahedral capsid shape. They are a large family of viruses that cause a variety of pathologies, the most pertinent in this 13-year-old boy with skin lesions on his fingers being HSV-1/HSV-2 (herpetic whitlow) and VZV (herpes zoster). However, herpetic skin lesions manifest with grouped, painful vesicles on an erythematous base, whereas this patient has flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules without surrounding erythema.

E) CORRECT:

HPV is a nonenveloped DNA virus with a circular, double-stranded genome and icosahedral capsid shape. Certain serotypes of HPV (particularly 1, 2, and 4) are the cause of common warts, which appear as skin-colored, scaly papules (sometimes with a cauliflower-like appearance) on the elbows, knees, fingers, and/or palms. This type of wart is most common in childhood and adolescence. Common warts are transmitted via close person-to-person contact, but other serotypes of HPV are sexually transmitted and can cause a variety of pathologies, including benign anogenital warts (serotypes 6 and 11) and cervical cancer (serotypes 16 and 18).
Image Description:

Multiple whitish plaques and papules are visible on the distal end of the fingers. A larger hyperkeratotic plaque with a verrucous and scaly surface can be seen on the distal end of the right thumb.

Common warts are typically associated with HPV infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Picornaviruses, hepeviruses, and caliciviruses are nonenveloped RNA viruses with a linear, single-stranded genome and icosahedral capsid shape. Picornaviruses include the Coxsackie A virus, which can manifest cutaneously in both herpangina and hand, foot, and mouth disease. Herpangina manifests with multiple, small vesicles on the posterior oropharynx. Hand, foot, and mouth disease manifests with oral ulcers and a maculopapular rash on the hands and feet. However, neither condition would cause superficial, flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules in an otherwise healthy pediatric patient.
questions.hint: This patient's physical examination findings suggest common warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

questions.text: A 3-month-old male infant with HIV infection is brought to the physician for evaluation. The physician recommends monthly intramuscular injections of a monoclonal antibody to protect against infection caused by an enveloped virus with a helical capsid and negative-sense, single-stranded RNA. The causal pathogen for this infection is most likely transmitted by which of the following routes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a pneumovirus that can cause bronchiolitis in infants. Pneumoviruses are enveloped viruses with a helical capsid and single-stranded, negative-sense, non-segmented, linear RNA. RSV is usually spread via droplet transmission or fomites (indirect contact transmission).

RSV prophylaxis with nirsevimab or palivizumab is recommended during RSV season in children ≤ 2 years of age at high risk of developing severe infection (e.g., those with chronic lung disease of prematurity).

B) INCORRECT:

The hepatitis C virus (HCV) is an enveloped RNA virus that can be transmitted by blood transfusion. However, HCV has an icosahedral capsid and positive sense RNA, and there is currently no FDA-approved monoclonal antibody to prevent HCV infection. The virus targeted by palivizumab is not blood-borne.

C) INCORRECT:

Rabies and Ebola fever are transmitted by inoculation of the virus into broken or damaged skin and caused by enveloped, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA viruses with a helical capsid. However, there is currently no FDA-approved monoclonal antibody to prevent either of these infections. The virus targeted by palivizumab is not transmitted via inoculation into the skin.

D) INCORRECT:

Human T-cell lymphotropic virus-1 (HTLV-1), which causes T-cell leukemia in patients with HIV infection, is an enveloped RNA virus that can be transmitted through breast milk. However, HTLV-1 has an icosahedral capsid and positive sense RNA, and there is currently no FDA-approved monoclonal antibody to prevent HTLV-1 infection. The virus targeted by palivizumab is not transmitted via breast milk.

E) INCORRECT:

Enveloped viruses are generally not transmitted via the fecal-oral route because these viruses are destroyed in the stomach's acidic environment. RNA viruses that are transmitted via the fecal-oral route include rotavirus, norovirus, poliovirus, coxsackievirus, echovirus, hepatitis A virus, and hepatitis E virus, which are all nonenveloped viruses with icosahedral capsids. Moreover, there is currently no FDA-approved monoclonal antibody to prevent infection by any of these nonenveloped RNA viruses.
questions.hint: Palivizumab is an FDA-approved monoclonal antibody used for infection prophylaxis. Palivizumab prevents infection by a particular pneumovirus.

questions.text: An investigator who studies virology obtains a biopsy from the ulcer base of an active genital herpes lesion for viral culture. The cultured virions, along with herpes simplex virions of a different phenotype, are cointroduced into a human epithelial cell in vitro. The progeny viruses are found to have phenotypes that are distinct from the parent strains. Sequencing of these progeny viruses shows that most genomes have material from both parent strains. These findings are best explained by which of the following terms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transformation (genetics) is a process by which bacteria actively take up and incorporate exogenous genetic material (e.g., from bacterial cell lysis) from the environment into their own genomes. This phenomenon occurs in some bacterial species and yeast but does not occur in viruses.

B) INCORRECT:

Complementation (viral) is a phenomenon in which one virus that has infected a cell has a mutation that results in production of a nonfunctional protein and a second virus that has coinfected that cell produces a normal protein that is used by both viruses (e.g., HBV codes for HBsAg, which can be used by Hepatitis D virus). No genetic information is exchanged; progeny viruses have a genotype derived from only one parent strain.
Image Description:

Complementation occurs when two viruses coinfect a host cell. One virus (virion A) produces a functional protein while the other (virion B) has a mutation in its genome that results in the production of a nonfunctional protein. Through complementation, the functional protein produced by virus A is used in both progeny A and B viruses. No genetic information is exchanged

For example, hepatitis D virus (HDV) can only cause infection in a host if a coinfection with hepatitis B virus occurs. Hepatitis D virus (HDV) uses the HBsAg, which is encoded in HBV, as an envelope protein.

C) CORRECT:

Viral recombination occurs when two homologous strands from different viral strains cross over to exchange segments of genetic material. The resulting viral progeny have a mix of genetic material that originates from both parental strains, which can lead to a new phenotype. Because viruses replicate intracellularly, this process only occurs when a cell is coinfected with different viral strains.

Like in meiosis I, the frequency of recombination observed between two loci is inversely correlated with the distance between those loci.
Image Description:

Recombination is the exchange of genetic material between two chromosomes of similar or related viral strains that have coinfected a host cell. The exchange occurs through crossing over of genes between two regions of homologous base sequences, which results in progeny with genetic material from two parental viral strains. This process increases genetic diversity in viral progeny.

D) INCORRECT:

Phenotypic mixing is a process in which the genome of one viral strain is coated with the surface proteins of a second viral strain that has infected the same cell. No genetic information is exchanged; progeny viruses have a genotype derived from only one parent strain.
Image Description:

Phenotypic mixing occurs with coinfection of a cell with two related viruses (virus A and virus B). The genome of virus A is partially or completely coated by the surface proteins of virus B, resulting in the formation of a pseudovirion (viral hybrid), comprising the genome of virus B and the surface proteins of virus A. The new protein coat determines the infectivity of the hybrid virus. Because no genetic information is exchanged, future generations lose their infectivity and return to their previous state (future virions will have the coat from virus B).

E) INCORRECT:

Reassortment (viral) occurs when segmented genomic strands from different viral strains that have coinfected the same cell are sorted into progeny. Though this can result in viral progeny that contains genetic material from multiple parent strains, this phenomenon does not occur in viruses with nonsegmented genomes, such as herpes simplex virus.
Image Description:

Viral reassortment is the exchange of genetic material between segments of two (or more) viruses of the same strain that have coinfected the same cell. Progeny has the new assortment of genetic material. This process only occurs in viruses with segmented genomes (e.g., influenza virus, rotavirus) and can cause antigenic shift, which significantly increases the pandemic potential of a virus.

F) INCORRECT:

Transduction (genetics) is a process of virally-mediated transfer and integration of DNA into a cell. Oftentimes, the DNA involved originates from a virion's previous host cell. This process introduces host cell DNA into viral progeny but would not cause the progeny to have genetic material from two parental viral strains.
questions.hint: An analogous process occurs in human gametes during meiosis I.

questions.text: An investigator studying influenza virus variability isolates several distinct influenza virus strains from the respiratory secretions of a study subject. Mass spectrometry analysis of one strain shows that it expresses neuraminidase on its surface. Subsequent sequencing of this strain shows that its genome lacks the neuraminidase gene. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transduction is a bacteriophage-mediated transfer of genetic material from one bacterium to another. It does not occur in viruses.

B) INCORRECT:

Viral reassortment is the exchange of genetic material in viruses with segmented genes (e.g., influenza virus). When a host becomes infected with different strains of influenza viruses, gene segments can be exchanged, producing a new strain. This can lead to antigenic shift and the development of pandemics in cases in which human and animal pathogenic strains exchange genetic material, as individuals will have no immunity against the new strain. The virus under investigation in this study has only been coated with a surface protein of a different strain and has not undergone a change in its genome.
Image Description:

Viral reassortment is the exchange of genetic material between segments of two (or more) viruses of the same strain that have coinfected the same cell. Progeny has the new assortment of genetic material. This process only occurs in viruses with segmented genomes (e.g., influenza virus, rotavirus) and can cause antigenic shift, which significantly increases the pandemic potential of a virus.

C) INCORRECT:

Recombination is the transfer and stabilization of genetic material between two adjacent chromosomes with significant sequence homology. It is a powerful genetic tool used for the development of gene therapy and vaccine. This phenomenon, however, does not explain the genotype-phenotype discrepancy of the influenza virus being studied here, which has not undergone a change in its genetic makeup.
Image Description:

Recombination is the exchange of genetic material between two chromosomes of similar or related viral strains that have coinfected a host cell. The exchange occurs through crossing over of genes between two regions of homologous base sequences, which results in progeny with genetic material from two parental viral strains. This process increases genetic diversity in viral progeny.

D) CORRECT:

Phenotypic mixing is the process by which a virus retains its own genetic material but becomes coated with surface proteins of a different coinfecting virus. This is observed in the influenza virus studied here, which expresses neuraminidase without having the actual genetic code. In some cases, phenotypic mixing can change a noninfectious virus into an infectious strain, as surface proteins determine host tropism. However, the surface protein will not be expressed in the subsequent progeny because it is not encoded in the viral genome.
Image Description:

Phenotypic mixing occurs with coinfection of a cell with two related viruses (virus A and virus B). The genome of virus A is partially or completely coated by the surface proteins of virus B, resulting in the formation of a pseudovirion (viral hybrid), comprising the genome of virus B and the surface proteins of virus A. The new protein coat determines the infectivity of the hybrid virus. Because no genetic information is exchanged, future generations lose their infectivity and return to their previous state (future virions will have the coat from virus B).

E) INCORRECT:

Complementation is the process by which a nonmutated virus produces a functional protein that a second mutated virus cannot produce and thus “complements” it. For instance, hepatitis D virus has a defective gene and does not express functional surface proteins needed for viral release and binding to host cells; it therefore depends on hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) to complement it so that it can propagate. In this study, the influenza virus does not have a defective gene but is missing the neuraminidase gene altogether.
Image Description:

Complementation occurs when two viruses coinfect a host cell. One virus (virion A) produces a functional protein while the other (virion B) has a mutation in its genome that results in the production of a nonfunctional protein. Through complementation, the functional protein produced by virus A is used in both progeny A and B viruses. No genetic information is exchanged

For example, hepatitis D virus (HDV) can only cause infection in a host if a coinfection with hepatitis B virus occurs. Hepatitis D virus (HDV) uses the HBsAg, which is encoded in HBV, as an envelope protein.
questions.hint: The influenza virus strain under investigation has surface neuraminidase without a genome encoding for the protein. It must have therefore acquired the surface protein from one of the other coinfecting influenza viruses.

questions.text: An investigator is studying bacterial toxins in a nonpathogenic bacterial monoculture that has been inoculated with specific bacteriophages. These phages were previously cultured in a toxin-producing bacterial culture. After inoculation, a new toxin is isolated from the culture. Genetic sequencing shows that the bacteria have incorporated viral genetic information, including the gene for this toxin, into their genome. The described process is most likely responsible for acquired pathogenicity in which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus acquires resistance to antibiotics such as vancomycin through transposition. The Tn1546 transposon moves from plasmid encoding vancomycin resistance in Enterococcus (VRE) to S. aureus during coinfection. Genes coding bacterial toxins are usually transferred by a different mechanism.
Image Description:

Bacterial transposition is a process by which genetic information is exchanged between bacteria or within the genome of the same bacterium via transposons.

Transposons (transposable elements or jumping genes) are DNA segments that can be excised from one location of the genome and re-inserted into another, thereby altering genetic expression (e.g., antibiotic resistance). Their action is brought about by transposase enzymes.

First step: The transposase enzyme binds to inverted repeat sequences (IR) flanking the transposons.
Second step: Transposase catalyzes the excision of the transposon sequence from the bacterial genome.
Third step: The target insertion site is recognized by transposase enzymes, which also catalyze the re-insertion of the transposon at this site.

B) CORRECT:

Nontoxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae can acquire the gene that encodes the diphtheria toxin through specialized transduction. This occurs when a toxigenic C. diphtheriae is infected with a lysogenic bacteriophage and the viral genome is inserted into the bacterial genome. As the phage replicates and excises its own nucleic acids from the bacterial genome to produce new phages, the flanking bacterial toxin gene is also copied to the new viruses. Any subsequent nontoxigenic bacteria infected with these phages will then acquire a copy of the toxin gene, which has become part of the phage genome. The genes for many other bacterial toxins such as erythrogenic exotoxin A, botulinum toxin, cholera toxin, and Shiga toxin are also transferred by specialized transduction.
Image Description:

Bacterial transduction is the process of gene transfer between bacteria via bacteriophages.

Top panel: generalized transduction (lytic cycle via virulent phages)
A bacteriophage attaches itself to the bacterial cell wall and injects its DNA into the bacterium. The viral DNA replicates within the infected bacterium and is incorporated into protein shells (phage capsids) to form numerous bacteriophages. The new bacteriophages lyse the bacterial cell wall and are released to infect other bacteria in the surrounding environment. A section of the bacterial genome may be incorporated into a viral capsid and be transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. As any portion of the bacterial genome may be transferred, in a process known as generalized transduction.

Bottom panel: specialized transduction (lysogenic and lytic cycle via temperate phages)
Once the bacteriophage has injected its DNA into the bacterium, the viral DNA is incorporated into the bacterial genome at a specific location and remains inactive as a prophage (lysogenic phase). Upon activation (e.g., with heat or UV radiation), the viral DNA replicates, is incorporated into phage capsids, and is released into the surrounding environment through lysing of the host bacterial cell wall (lytic phase). During this process, the bacterial DNA flanking the viral DNA is also incorporated into the viral capsid and transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. Because a specific portion of the bacterial genome is being transferred, the process is known as specialized transduction.

The panel on the right summarizes the major difference between generalized and specialized transduction.

C) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae acquires virulence factors through bacterial transformation, in which exogenous genetic material is taken up and expressed. Bacterial transformation is not dependent on the presence or absence of bacteriophages.
Image Description:

Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis acquires virulence factors through bacterial transformation, in which exogenous genetic material is taken up and expressed. Bacterial transformation is not dependent on the presence or absence of bacteriophages.
Image Description:

Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae acquire virulence factors through bacterial transformation, in which exogenous genetic material is taken up and expressed. Bacterial transformation is not dependent on the presence or absence of bacteriophages.
Image Description:

Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).
questions.hint: The virus has infected the previously nonpathogenic bacteria and incorporated its own viral genetic information into the bacterial genome, giving the bacteria a new virulence factor. This process is called specialized transduction.

questions.text: An investigator studying viral mutation isolates a virus strain from the gastric contents of an infant with gastroenteritis. This virus has a nonenveloped RNA genome with 11 segments and an icosahedral capsid. The investigator finds that if 2 strains of this virus coinfect a single host cell, some of the resulting viral progeny have genome segments derived from both parental viruses. The observed phenomenon can also occur with which of the following viral families?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flaviviruses (e.g., Zika virus, West Nile virus, hepatitis C virus) are nonsegmented RNA viruses and cannot undergo viral reassortment.

B) INCORRECT:

Members of Coronaviridae (e.g., SARS virus) are nonsegmented RNA viruses and cannot undergo viral reassortment.

C) CORRECT:

Viral reassortment can only occur with segmented RNA viruses, which include the nonenveloped reoviruses (e.g., rotavirus) and the enveloped orthomyxoviruses (e.g., influenza virus), bunyaviruses, and arenaviruses. Viral reassortment leads to antigenic shifts, which can cause pandemics and make existing vaccines ineffective against the new progeny. For example, influenza virus strains can reassort yearly and new vaccines against the new influenza virus strains must be manufactured annually.

In contrast to the significant changes in the viral genome associated with antigenic shifts, antigenic drifts due to point mutations only result in minor genetic differences. Antigenic drifts can occur with any virus.

D) INCORRECT:

Caliciviruses (e.g., norovirus) are nonsegmented RNA viruses, which cannot undergo viral reassortment.

E) INCORRECT:

Picornaviruses (e.g., enteroviruses, hepatitis A virus, poliovirus) do not undergo viral reassortment because they lack a segmented genome.

F) INCORRECT:

Retroviruses (e.g., human immunodeficiency virus, human T-lymphotropic virus) are RNA viruses that use a DNA intermediate to incorporate their own genetic codes into the host cell's genome. Retroviruses are nonsegmented RNA viruses and cannot undergo viral reassortment.
questions.hint: The process of exchanging entire RNA segments to create viral progeny with merged segments from multiple infecting strains is known as viral reassortment and can only occur in viruses with segmented genomes.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of dysuria and increased urinary frequency. Vital signs are within normal limits. Urinalysis shows cloudy, red urine. This patient's clinical presentation is best explained by an infection with a virus with which of the following features?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus is a nonenveloped virus with a linear, single-stranded DNA. This virus causes erythema infectiosum in children, which is characterized by fever, circumoral pallor, a bright red rash on the cheeks, and a reticular rash on the trunk and extremities. Parvovirus does not cause acute hemorrhagic cystitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Picornaviruses, hepeviruses, and caliciviruses are nonenveloped viruses with linear, single-stranded RNA. None of these viruses cause acute hemorrhagic cystitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Poxviruses and herpesviruses are both enveloped viruses with linear, double-stranded DNA. Although hemorrhagic cystitis due to HSV-2 has been reported, it is an extremely rare presentation that occurs in immunosuppressed patients. Childhood infections typically associated with enveloped, double-stranded linear DNA viruses include chickenpox (HHV-3), infectious mononucleosis (HHV-4), roseola infantum (HHV-6, HHV-7), and molluscum contagiosum (poxvirus).

D) INCORRECT:

The enveloped, single-stranded linear RNA viruses most commonly associated with childhood infections are coronaviruses (common cold), orthomyxoviruses (influenza), paramyxoviruses (croup, bronchiolitis, mumps, measles), and togaviruses (rubella). Hemorrhagic cystitis due to the orthomyxovirus influenza A has been reported, but this is an extremely rare clinical presentation.

Other enveloped, single-stranded linear RNA viruses such as flaviviruses, retroviruses, rhabdoviruses, and filoviruses only rarely affect children and do not cause hemorrhagic cystitis.

E) CORRECT:

Adenoviruses are nonenveloped viruses with linear, double-stranded DNA and an icosahedral capsid. Serotypes 7, 11, 21, and 35 cause acute viral hemorrhagic cystitis. This condition occurs most frequently among male children and typically manifests with dysuria and hematuria that resolves within days to weeks after onset. Adenovirus infection is also associated with febrile pharyngitis, pneumonia, conjunctivitis, gastroenteritis, and myocarditis.
questions.hint: This boy has dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and bloody urine on urinalysis. These signs and symptoms suggest acute hemorrhagic cystitis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and itchy, red eyes. His symptoms began while he was away at summer camp. His immunizations are not up-to-date. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows erythema and edema of the conjunctivae and posterior pharyngeal wall. There is bilateral, tender, preauricular lymphadenopathy. Further evaluation shows infection with a DNA virus. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Adenovirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with a linear structure and the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms. Conjunctivitis and febrile pharyngitis occurring simultaneously in a patient who has spent time in close proximity to other individuals (e.g., summer camp) is highly suspicious for adenovirus infection. Apart from pharyngoconjunctivitis, adenovirus may cause gastroenteritis, pneumonia, acute hemorrhagic cystitis, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus is a nonenveloped, single-stranded DNA virus and the causative organism of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). Fifth disease most commonly manifests with mild, cold-like symptoms, similar to this patient's presentation, after which a characteristic rash on the cheeks develops (slapped-cheek rash). The lack of rash in this patient, taken together with the simultaneous appearance of both pharyngitis and conjunctivitis, make another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Picornaviridae comprise a heterogeneous group of viruses that are associated with a wide variety of diseases ranging from the common cold (rhinovirus) to viral meningitis (e.g., coxsackievirus, echovirus). However, picornaviridae are nonenveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses, whereas this patient has a DNA virus. Moreover, the picornaviridae are not specifically linked to pharyngoconjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Paramyxoviridae are a family of several viruses including the parainfluenza virus, mumps virus, and measles virus. Measles causes findings similar to those of this patient, including conjunctivitis, fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. Moreover, an incomplete vaccination history could support the suspicion of measles in a 10-year-old child. However, this patient does not have a rash, as a measles patient likely would. Furthermore, paramyxoviridae are RNA viruses, while this patient has a DNA virus.

E) INCORRECT:

Human herpes virus 6 is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with a linear structure associated with the development of roseola infantum. Roseola manifests with high fever for a few days, followed by a rapid return to an afebrile state and the onset of a maculopapular rash. Affected individuals may also develop pharyngitis and conjunctivitis, which would be consistent with this patient's presentation. However, this patient's age makes roseola very unlikely, as most individuals are seropositive by the age of 3. Also, postoccipital lymphadenopathy rather than preauricular is more characteristic of roseola.

F) INCORRECT:

Human herpes virus 4, better known as Epstein-Barr virus, is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus and the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. The pharyngitis seen in this patient could be attributed to mono. However, individuals with mono would not be expected to present with conjunctivitis or preauricular lymphadenopathy, but rather, with hepatosplenomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of pharyngoconjunctival fever, a classic manifestation of a specific viral infection.

questions.text: An investigator studying patients with symptoms of arthritis detects a nonenveloped virus with a single-stranded DNA genome in the serum of a pregnant patient. Fetal infection with this pathogen is most likely to cause which of the following manifestations?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19, a congenital TORCH infection, can lead to the development of hydrops fetalis during pregnancy. Infection of RBCs by this virus induces apoptosis and massive destruction of erythroid lineage cells, causing severe anemia and heart failure in the fetus (secondary to excessive fluid accumulation within the fetal vascular compartments). This often fatal condition can also be caused by chromosomal abnormalities, inborn errors of metabolism, Rh incompatibility, lymphatic dysplasia, and Treponema pallidum infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Chorioretinitis in a fetus is often due to an infection with Toxoplasma gondii or cytomegalovirus (CMV). These intrauterine infections are also associated with hydrocephalus and intracranial calcifications (periventricular with CMV). However, T. gondii is a protozoan, and CMV is an enveloped dsDNA virus, in contrast to the nonenveloped ssDNA virus being studied. Furthermore, neither of these infections are known to cause arthritis in adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Microcephaly in a fetus may be due to an infection with Zika virus (a Flavivirus). This intrauterine infection may also present with mild fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. Although Zika virus can cause arthralgias in adults, it is an enveloped ssRNA virus, unlike the nonenveloped ssDNA virus identified by the investigator.

D) INCORRECT:

Notched, widely spaced teeth in a young child is a highly suggestive finding of a congenital infection with Treponema pallidum (a Spirochete). This infection may also present with sensorineural deafness, facial abnormalities (saddle nose, short maxilla), saber shins, and hydrops fetalis. T. pallidum is a bacterium, not a virus.

E) INCORRECT:

Sensorineural hearing loss in a fetus may be due to an infection with rubella virus, Treponema pallidum, or cytomegalovirus (CMV). While both rubella and T. pallidum (secondary syphilis) may cause arthritis in adult patients, rubella is an enveloped ssRNA virus, T. pallidum is a bacteria, and CMV is a dsDNA virus. Therefore, none of these infections fit the nonenveloped ssDNA virus profile identified by the investigator.

F) INCORRECT:

A vesicular rash in a fetus is highly suggestive of an intrauterine or perinatal infection with herpes simplex virus (typically HSV-2). This infection can lead to a variety of clinical features including fetal demise, microcephaly, and meningoencephalitis. The HSV-2 virus is an enveloped dsDNA virus, unlike the nonenveloped ssDNA virus identified by the investigator.
questions.hint: Parvovirus B19 is one of the few nonenveloped ssDNA viruses that infect humans. It can lead to transplacental fetal infection.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effect that mutations in different parts of the respiratory tract have on susceptibility to infection. A mutation in the gene encoding for the CD21 protein is induced in a sample of cells obtained from the nasopharyngeal epithelium. This mutation is most likely to prevent infection with which of the following viruses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rhinovirus is transmitted directly from person to person, via contaminated surfaces, and via airborne droplets. Its proliferation is limited to the local portals of entry (nasopharyngeal epithelium). However, it attaches to ICAM-1 receptors (CD54) on respiratory epithelial cells, not CD21.

B) CORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is initially transmitted via saliva and first replicates in epithelial cells in the oropharynx. It then infects B cells through interaction of EBV envelope glycoprotein gp350 with CD21 and spreads to the lymph nodes, where it triggers a T-cell mediated immune response. A mutation in the gene encoding CD21 would therefore prevent EBV infection.

See “Receptors used by viruses” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) enters the body via mucosal lesions and attaches to the CD4 receptor on target cells (e.g., T lymphocytes, macrophages) with its GP120 glycoprotein. The viral envelope, however, only fuses with the host cell when a coreceptor (CCR5) is also present. CD21 does not play a role in HIV infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is spread via secretions (e.g., saliva) and binds to heparan sulfate proteoglycans, thereby inducing cellular morphological changes with subsequent apoptosis. CD21 does not play a role in CMV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 is mainly transmitted through droplets. It attaches to P antigen on RBCs and propagates primarily in progenitor cells of erythrocytes, particularly in bone marrow. CD21 does not play a role in parvovirus B19 infection.
questions.hint: Infection with this virus is associated with various lymphoproliferative disorders, including post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease.

questions.text: An investigator studying the immunologic profile of various cells notices that the blood of a test subject agglutinates upon addition of a serum containing antibodies against P blood group antigens. Infection with which of the following pathogens would most likely be prevented by these antibodies?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 has been shown to cause aplastic anemia by binding to blood group P antigens (measured by hemagglutination). The absence of P antigens or administration of a monoclonal antibody to globosides, an essential component of the P antigen that functions as a receptor, confers parvovirus B19 immunity.

B) INCORRECT:

Babesia microti binds to neuraminidase-sensitive and trypsin-sensitive receptors on RBCs to invade and cause hemolytic disease (babesiosis). It does not interact with P antigens.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasmodium vivax binds to the Duffy antigen found on RBCs, and RBCs lacking the duffy glycoprotein are relatively resistant to P. vivax invasion. P. vivax does not interact with P antigens.

D) INCORRECT:

EBV invades cells by binding to the complement receptor CD21 on normal human B lymphocytes, triggering the signal pathway required for infection. EBV does not interact with P antigens, nor does it invade erythrocytes.

E) INCORRECT:

The influenza virus preferentially binds to sialic acids present on the surface of erythrocytes and respiratory cells to invade and cause disease. Sialic acids are not a component of blood group P antigens.
questions.hint: This pathogen can cause severe anemia in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever and painful lesions on her left index finger. Two weeks ago, she had a painful rash on the right labia majora that resolved without treatment. Physical examination shows tender lymphadenopathy of the left epitrochlear and right inguinal region. A photograph of the left index finger is shown. Which of the following best describes the properties of the most likely virus involved?

choices.text: Naked virus with a double-stranded, circular DNA structure
Naked virus with a single-stranded, positive sense, linear RNA structure
Enveloped virus with a double-stranded, linear DNA structure
Enveloped virus with a single-stranded, negative sense, linear RNA structure
Enveloped virus with a partially double-stranded, circular DNA structure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Non-enveloped (naked) viruses with a double-stranded, circular DNA structure include papillomaviruses (e.g., HPV, which causes common warts and genital warts) and polyomaviruses (e.g., JC virus, which causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy). None of these viruses cause the painful vesicles seen in this case.
Image Description:

Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

B) INCORRECT:

Non-enveloped (naked) viruses with a single-stranded, positive sense, linear RNA structure include picornaviruses (e.g., poliovirus, coxsackievirus), hepeviruses (e.g., hepatitis E virus), and caliciviruses (e.g., norovirus). Coxsackie A virus causes hand, foot, and mouth disease, which can manifest with a vesicular rash on the hands and fever but typically also causes oral ulcers and lesions on the feet. In addition, this condition most commonly infects children under 10 years of age. This woman's history of a genital rash makes another infection more likely. None of the other viruses with these characteristics cause the painful vesicles seen in this case.
Image Description:

Hands and feet of a 36-year-old male patient

Macular and papular lesions are visible on the inner surface of the hands and feet.

The localization in conjunction with the enanthem of the mucous membranes is typical of hand, foot, and mouth disease.

C) CORRECT:

The herpes simplex virus is an enveloped virus with a double-stranded, linear DNA structure that causes HSV-1 and HSV-2 infections. The envelope is a lipid bilayer around an icosahedral capsid that contains viral glycoproteins and proteins from the host cell; it helps the virus fuse with and infect host cells.
Image Description:

Viruses can be distinguished based on whether there is an envelope and the form of the capsid. The genome, consisting of either DNA or RNA, may be single-stranded (ss) or double-stranded (ds).

D) INCORRECT:

Enveloped viruses with a single-stranded, negative sense, linear RNA structure include orthomyxoviruses (e.g., influenza virus), paramyxoviruses (e.g., parainfluenza virus), rhabdoviruses (e.g., rabies virus), and filoviruses (e.g., Ebola virus). None of these viruses cause the painful vesicles seen in this case.
Image Description:

Colored electron micrograph of an influenza virion

The central ribonucleoproteins (purple, contains the virus genome and other proteins), matrix (brown), double lipid membrane of the virus envelope (yellow), and membrane proteins (orange) can be seen. The influenza virus strain type is characterized by the constituents of the membrane proteins (especially hemagglutinin [H] and neuraminidase [N]) (e.g., H1N1: swine flu).

E) INCORRECT:

Hepadnaviruses (e.g., hepatitis B virus) are enveloped and have a partially double-stranded, circular DNA structure. Hepatitis B virus causes acute and chronic hepatitis but does not cause the painful vesicles seen in this case.
Image Description:

Electron micrograph of hepatitis B virus

Different forms of virus particles are present. In the center, large, circular virus particles can be seen, which are surrounded by filamentous particles and smaller spherical particles.

The circular particles are infectious virus particles, also called Dane particles, which consist of a nucleocapsid and core proteins. The filamentous and spherical particles only consist of the lipid envelope and are therefore noninfectious.

D: Dane particle or virion; F: filamentous viral particle; S: spherical viral particle
questions.hint: This woman has herpetic whitlow, which manifests with a painful, vesicular rash on the fingers. This infection is caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV)-1 or HSV-2. In this patient with a history of a genital rash, HSV-2 is the most likely causal organism.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fatigue, weight loss, and painless swellings in the neck and armpit. She returned from a trip to visit her family in southern Japan 1 month ago. Physical examination shows cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Her serum calcium concentration is 11.1 mg/dL. An x-ray of the skull shows multiple lytic bone lesions. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei that resemble clover leaves. These cells stain positive for CD3, CD4, and CD7. Which of the following best describes the properties of the causal virus of this patient's condition?



Type of nucleic acid
Envelope
Capsid symmetry



A
Partially double-stranded DNA, circular
yes
icosahedral


B
Single-stranded RNA, linear
yes
icosahedral


C
Double-stranded RNA, linear
no
icosahedral (double)


D
Single-stranded RNA, linear
yes
complex


E
Double-stranded DNA, circular
no
icosahedral
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B virus is an enveloped, partially double-stranded, circular DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. This virus is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma but not with adult T cell leukemia-lymphoma.

B) CORRECT:

Human T-cell lymphotropic virus (HTLV-1) is an enveloped, linear, single-stranded RNA retrovirus with an icosahedral capsid. HTLV-1 is endemic in Japan, West Africa, and the Caribbean. Most patients infected with HTLV-1 remain asymptomatic. Conditions associated with this infection include adult T-cell leukemia-lymphoma and HTLV-1 associated myelopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Coltivirus and rotavirus are both non-enveloped, double-stranded, linear RNA viruses with a double icosahedral capsid structure. Coltivirus causes Colorado tick fever, and rotavirus causes viral gastroenteritis in young children. Neither of them is associated with adult T cell leukemia-lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is an enveloped, linear, single-stranded RNA virus with a complex capsid. Although acute HIV infection can manifest with fatigue and painless lymphadenopathy, HIV is not associated with adult T cell leukemia-lymphoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) and polyomavirus are both non-enveloped, circular, double-stranded DNA viruses with icosahedral capsids. HPV is associated with malignancies such as cervical cancer, penile cancer, anal cancer, and head and neck cancer. Polyomaviruses include JC virus, which is associated with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, and BK virus, which is associated with nephropathy and hemorrhagic cystitis, especially in transplant recipients. None of these viruses is associated with adult T cell leukemia-lymphoma.
questions.hint: This patient's B symptoms, painless lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly raise suspicion for a lymphoid neoplasm. Hypercalcemia, lytic bone lesions, and hyperlobulated lymphocytes that stain positive for T cell markers are suggestive of a diagnosis of adult T cell leukemia-lymphoma, which is associated with human T-lymphotropic virus, type 1 (HTLV-1).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of intravenous drug use is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fatigue, yellow eyes, confusion, and blood in her stools. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Physical examination shows pain in the right upper quadrant, diffuse jaundice with scleral icterus, and bright red blood in the rectal vault. Further evaluation demonstrates virions in her blood, some of which have a partially double-stranded DNA genome while others have a single-stranded RNA genome. They are found to share an identical lipoprotein envelope. This patient is most likely infected with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Picornaviruses are single-stranded RNA viruses and include the hepatitis A virus (HAV), which would cause acute hepatitis. However, picornaviruses do not have an envelope, and liver failure occurs in < 1% of HAV infections. Moreover, HAV is transmitted via the fecal‑oral route (contaminated food or water), not via injection drug use.

B) INCORRECT:

Caliciviruses are single-stranded RNA viruses. Norovirus, which is the most clinically relevant calicivirus, causes gastroenteritis. It does not cause hepatitis. Additionally, noroviruses are non-enveloped viruses, unlike the enveloped RNA virus in this patient, and norovirus is transmitted via the fecal‑oral route (contaminated food or water), not via injection drug use.

C) INCORRECT:

Flaviviridae are enveloped single-stranded RNA viruses. Hepatitis C virus (HCV), which is a flavivirus, can cause acute hepatitis. Also, coinfection of HBV (a double-stranded DNA virus) with HCV can occur because both HCV and HBV are transmitted via contaminated needles, and the risk of fulminant hepatic failure due to acute HCV hepatitis is increased if the patient has an underlying HBV infection. However, flaviviruses and HBV do not share an identical envelope.

D) INCORRECT:

Filoviruses (e.g., Ebola virus, Marburg virus) are enveloped single-stranded RNA viruses can cause fever, hepatitis, and rectal bleeding (viral hemorrhagic fever) and can be transmitted via needle sticks contaminated with body fluids. However, filoviruses do not have a lipoprotein envelope that is identical to any DNA virus. Moreover, filovirus infections occur in sub-Saharan Africa. Filoviruses are not endemic to the continental US. The few cases that have been reported in the US were attributed to travel to an endemic region.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepeviruses are single-stranded RNA viruses. Hepatitis E virus (HEV), which is the most clinically relevant hepevirus, would cause acute viral hepatitis. However, HEV does not have a lipoprotein envelope. Moreover, HEV is transmitted via the fecal‑oral route (contaminated food or water), not via injection drug use, and hepatic failure does not typically occur with HEV hepatitis unless the patient is pregnant.

F) INCORRECT:

Herpesviruses are enveloped double-stranded DNA viruses. Certain herpesviruses such as CMV, EBV, and HSV would cause fever and, rarely, hepatitis, especially when associated with coinfection by HIV, which is an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus. However, HIV and herpesviruses do not share an identical lipoprotein envelope. Moreover, patients who have been infected acutely by any of the aforementioned herpesviruses would also have other characteristic clinical features (e.g., pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy in the case of EBV infection, vesicular rash in the case of HSV infection).

G) CORRECT:

Hepatitis B virus (HBV) and hepatitis D virus (HDV) are transmitted sexually, parenterally (e.g., contaminated shared needles), or perinatally. Acute HBV infection is usually mild or asymptomatic and resolves within a few weeks or months. However, 5% of adult patients will develop chronic HBV infection. HDV, on the other hand, is a defective virus that is dependent on the HBsAg coat of HBV for entry into hepatocytes. Therefore, HDV can only cause infection if simultaneous infection with HBV occurs or if the patient already has a chronic HBV infection. Simultaneous infection of HBV with HDV usually has a protracted course but superinfection by HDV in a patient with pre-existing HBV infection often has a rapid course characterized by fulminant hepatic failure, as seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of acute viral hepatitis (e.g., fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant tenderness) and hepatic failure (e.g., confusion due to encephalopathy, rectal bleeding due to coagulopathy). Her history of intravenous drug use puts her at risk of infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV), which is an enveloped partially double-stranded DNA virus. The presence of virions with a single-stranded RNA genome and an envelope with lipoproteins identical to those in HBV virus indicates that the patient is concurrently infected with the hepatitis D virus.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the structural characteristics of pathogenic viruses. Cell cultures infected by different viruses are observed under a scanning electron microscope. One of the cell samples is infected by a virus that has an envelope composed of nuclear membrane molecules. The most likely virus that has infected this cell sample can cause which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Influenza is caused by the influenza virus, a type of orthomyxovirus. These viruses derive their envelope from host cell plasma membranes, not host cell nuclear membranes.

B) INCORRECT:

Yellow fever is caused by a flavivirus. These viruses derive their envelope from host cell plasma membranes, not host cell nuclear membranes.

C) CORRECT:

Shingles is a dermatomal rash with painful blistering caused by reactivation of the varicella zoster virus, which belongs to the family of herpesviruses. Herpesviruses are the only viruses that acquire their primary envelope from host cell nuclear membranes; most other viruses acquire their envelope from host cell plasma membranes.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19. Parvoviruses are non-enveloped; their outer shell is not covered by a lipid membrane.

E) INCORRECT:

Ebola is caused by the Ebola virus, a type of filovirus. These viruses derive their envelope from host cell plasma membranes, not host cell nuclear membranes.
questions.hint: Most viral envelopes are derived from portions of the host plasma membrane. Only one particular family of DNA viruses acquires its envelope from host nuclear membranes.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of generalized fatigue, myalgia, and a pruritic skin rash for the past 5 months. As a child, he was involved in a motor vehicle accident and required several blood transfusions. Physical examination shows right upper abdominal tenderness, scleral icterus, and well-demarcated, purple, polygonal papules on the wrists bilaterally. Laboratory studies show an elevated replication rate of a hepatotropic virus. Further analysis shows high variability in the genetic sequence that encodes the glycosylated envelope proteins produced by this virus. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the variability in the genetic sequence of these proteins?

choices.text: Neutralizing host antibodies induce viral genome mutations
Viral RNA polymerase lacks proofreading ability
Incorporation of envelope proteins from a second virus
Integration of viral genes into host cell genome

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because HCV continuously produces antigenically unique virions, host antibodies cannot confer immunity to the virus. Meanwhile, the production of host antibodies does not drive the virus to create antigenically unique virions. These antibodies are unable to exert selection pressure, which would otherwise encourage viral mutations. Instead, the virus innately mutates and produces antigenically unique virions that drive the continued production of unique antibodies by the host.

B) CORRECT:

Hepatitis C virus RNA-dependent RNA polymerase has a very poor proofreading mechanism, leading to frequent errors in viral genes. These errors manifest as variations in the structure of viral proteins. Mutations in the viral glycoprotein envelope allow for antigenic variation and evasion of the host antibody response to these envelope proteins. In addition, HCV replicates very quickly, which enhances the effect of poor proofreading and accelerates the production of antigenically distinct envelopes.

C) INCORRECT:

Incorporation of envelope proteins from a second virus does not affect the ability of hepatitis C virions to evade the host immune system. Hepatitis D virus, for example, lacks the genes required to synthesize an envelope, so it relies on the envelope of the hepatitis B virus for entry into host hepatocytes. Therefore, hepatitis D viral infection can only occur as a coinfection (both hepatitis D and B simultaneously) or superinfection (hepatitis D after hepatitis B) with hepatitis B.

D) INCORRECT:

Integration of viral genes into the host cell genome is not a feature of the HCV lifecycle or pathophysiology.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with multiple viral genotypes is possible in patients with HCV because there are six genotypes of the virus. Patients infected with multiple strains most commonly have a history of intravenous drug use. It is unlikely that this patient contracted more than one genotype of HCV from his previous blood transfusions. Also, infection with more than one viral strain does not explain the variability in the genetic sequence of these viral proteins.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of viral hepatitis. His history of blood transfusions before 1992, the year in which screening for the hepatitis C virus (HCV) in donor blood began, suggests chronic hepatitis C. The pruritic skin rash on the wrists is most likely lichen planus, a common extrahepatic manifestation of chronic infection.

questions.text: During an experiment conducted to alter the infectivity of common viruses that affect humans, an investigator successfully increases the host range of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The new strain of the virus can infect fibroblast-like cells in addition to the usual target of HIV. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the increase in the host range of the virus?

choices.text: Mutation of the gene coding for viral surface glycoproteins
Point mutations in the hemagglutinin gene
Increased rate of budding out of host cells
Reassortment of genetic material between segments of two viruses
Excessive activity of viral RNA polymerase

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Viral surface glycoproteins determine which host cells the virus can attach to and penetrate, meaning a mutation to their genes could increase the host range of the virus.

B) INCORRECT:

Point mutations in the hemagglutinin gene cause antigenic drift, after which altered hemagglutinin glycoprotein will not be effectively neutralized by any host antibodies that originally targeted previous strains. Although a mutation in the hemagglutinin gene can alter the host range, this gene is found in influenza virus, not HIV.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral budding, which occurs in enveloped viruses such as HIV, promotes the spread of viral infection. However, this process does not affect the host range as it is not involved in host attachment and penetration.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassortment of genetic material between segments of two viruses can cause antigenic shift. Although it can alter host range, reassortment affects segmented viruses such as influenza A virus, not HIV.

E) INCORRECT:

Viral RNA polymerase catalyzes the transcription of RNA from an RNA template. This process does not affect host range as it has no role in viral attachment and penetration. Moreover, HIV virus has reverse transcriptase, not RNA polymerase.
questions.hint: Host range is determined by the virus' ability to attach to host cell receptors.

questions.text: An investigator studying viral replication isolates the genetic material of an unidentified virus strain. After exposing a cell culture to the isolated, purified viral genetic material, the cells begin to produce viral polymerase and subsequently replicate the viral genome. Infection with the investigated strain is most likely to cause which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measles virus is a single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus of the paramyxovirus family. It has its own RNA-dependent RNA polymerase to convert negative-sense RNA to positive-sense RNA before translation. In the absence of its own polymerase, the viral genetic material cannot be replicated, and the viral life cycle stalls.

B) INCORRECT:

Rotavirus is a double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) virus of the reovirus family. Rotavirus uses its own RNA polymerase to transcribe dsRNA into positive-sense, single-stranded RNA before translation in the host cell cytoplasm. In the absence of this specialized polymerase, the viral genome cannot be replicated, and the viral life cycle stalls.

C) INCORRECT:

Influenza viruses are single-stranded, negative-sense RNA viruses of the orthomyxovirus family. These viruses convert negative-sense RNA to positive-sense RNA before translation using their own RNA-dependent RNA polymerases. In the absence of its own polymerase, the viral genetic material cannot be replicated, and the viral life cycle stalls.

D) INCORRECT:

Rabies virus is a single-stranded negative-sense RNA virus. It requires its own RNA-dependent RNA polymerase to convert it to a positive sense RNA template before replication. In the absence of its own polymerase, the viral genetic material cannot be replicated and the viral life cycle stalls.

E) CORRECT:

Poliovirus is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA ((+)ssRNA) virus. The genetic material of (+)ssRNA viruses, which is essentially equivalent to eukaryotic mRNA, can be readily translated by the host cell into the proteins necessary for the viral life cycle, including viral polymerases. Viral genetic fragments are infectious because an intact virion is not necessary for viral reproduction. All other (+)ssRNA viruses have this capability, including rhinovirus, coxsackieviruses, echovirus, and hepatitis A virus.

The genetic material of double-stranded DNA viruses is also considered infectious because eukaryotic cells will ultimately transcribe the viral genome into mRNA, which can be translated into viral proteins and thus propagate the viral life cycle in the absence of intact virions.
questions.hint: Purified nucleic acids of most double-stranded DNA viruses and positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses are infectious. In contrast, naked nucleic acids of double-stranded RNA viruses and negative-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses require polymerase to form a positive-sense RNA prior to translation.

questions.text: The occupational health department at a hospital implements new safety precautions to prevent laboratory-acquired infections. One of the new precautions includes disinfecting the microbiology laboratory benches with 70% ethanol before and after use. This measure is most likely to be effective in preventing the transmission of which of the following viruses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) belongs to the family of picornaviruses, which are non-enveloped RNA viruses. Ethyl alcohol at a concentration of 60–80% has been shown to inactivate certain picornaviruses such as rhinovirus, but HAV is typically resistant to inactivation by alcohol. Enveloped viruses such as hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, and hepatitis D virus can be inactivated by alcohol.

B) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus is a non-enveloped DNA virus. Ethyl alcohol at a concentration of 60–80% has been shown to inactivate certain non-enveloped viruses such as adenovirus, rhinovirus, and rotaviruses. However, most other non-enveloped viruses, including parvovirus, are typically resistant to inactivation by alcohol.

C) INCORRECT:

Poliovirus virus belongs to the family of picornaviruses, which are non-enveloped RNA viruses. Ethyl alcohol at a concentration of 60–80% has been shown to inactivate certain picornaviruses such as rhinovirus, but poliovirus is typically resistant to inactivation by alcohol.

D) INCORRECT:

Polyomavirus is a non-enveloped DNA virus. Ethyl alcohol at a concentration of 60–80% has been shown to inactivate certain non-enveloped viruses such as adenovirus, rhinovirus, and rotaviruses. However, most other non-enveloped viruses, including polyomavirus, are typically resistant to inactivation by alcohol.

E) CORRECT:

Alcohols and other organic solvents disrupt plasma membranes and are effective in inactivating nearly all enveloped viruses, including herpesviruses (e.g., herpes simplex virus). The important exception is rhabdoviruses (e.g., rabies virus), which is resistant to ethyl alcohol but can be inactivated by 70% isopropyl alcohol. Ethyl alcohol at a concentration of 60–80% has also been shown to inactivate certain non-enveloped viruses such as adenovirus, rhinovirus, and rotavirus, but most other non-enveloped viruses are typically resistant to inactivation by alcohol.
questions.hint: Ethyl alcohol at concentrations of 60–80% is a potent virucidal agent that is effective against enveloped viruses.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the replication of a virus in denucleated embryonic fibroblasts. After the fibroblasts are infected with the virus, viral proteins are directly translated from the virion's genetic material using fibroblast ribosomes. The resultant large polypeptides are then cleaved into smaller peptides by viral proteases to generate mature viral proteins. Finally, the virion's genetic material is replicated using a protein translated from the virion's genetic material. Which of the following is the most likely virus being evaluated in this study?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HIV (retrovirus) is a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that uses proteases contained within the virion to cleave translated viral proteins. However, retroviruses are unique among positive-sense RNA viruses because their genetic material is not used to directly translate proteins but to synthesize DNA using reverse transcriptase contained within the virion. This DNA (provirus) is subsequently integrated into the host's DNA located in the nucleus and the host's machinery for mRNA synthesis and protein translation is used to synthesize HIV's RNA and structural proteins. Since the nucleus is an integral part of this process, HIV would not be able to replicate its genetic material in denucleated fibroblasts.

B) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus is a DNA virus. Proteins cannot be translated directly from DNA but from an mRNA intermediate that is synthesized from DNA. Furthermore, most DNA viruses replicate their genetic material in the nucleus using host cell's DNA-dependent DNA polymerase unlike this virion's genetic material, which is replicated in the cytoplasm of denucleated fibroblasts using a protein translated from the virion's genetic material.
Image Description:

In the viral life cycle, the genome of the DNA virus enters the nucleus after uncoating. In the nucleus, the viral DNA is integrated into the host DNA and is subsequently transcribed and replicated by the host cell machinery.

Nuclear entry, which does not occur in the RNA virus life cycle, is the distinguishing feature of the DNA virus life cycle.

C) INCORRECT:

Influenza virus (orthomyxovirus) is a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. Influenza virus is one of the few RNA viruses that replicate their genetic material in the nucleus and would, therefore, be unable to replicate in denucleated fibroblasts. Furthermore, viral proteins can be translated directly only from positive-sense RNA, which can function as mRNA. Negative-sense RNA viruses must first synthesize a positive-sense RNA using an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase contained in the virion before proteins can be translated.

D) INCORRECT:

Poxviruses such as the molluscum contagiosum virus are unique among DNA viruses in that they can replicate their genetic material in the cytoplasm, as seen here. This is because poxviruses contain a DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which can be used to transcribe mRNA. The mRNA is then translated by the host's cytoplasmic protein translation machinery (e.g., free ribosomes) to synthesize enzymes needed for DNA replication (e.g., DNA polymerase). However, like with all DNA viruses, proteins cannot be translated directly from DNA but from the RNA, which is not the genetic material of poxviruses.

E) CORRECT:

Coxsackievirus is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus. Positive-sense RNA, which can function as mRNA, is directly translated by host ribosomes to form proteins in the cytoplasm. These viral proteins create a replication complex with RNA-dependent RNA polymerase activity, which synthesizes an intermediate strand of negative-sense RNA. This strand is subsequently used as a template to synthesize positive-sense RNA. With the exception of retroviruses and influenza virus, the replication of most RNA viruses does not require the presence of the nucleus and can proceed as long as the host's cytoplasmic protein translation machinery (e.g., free ribosomes) is intact.

Viral proteases, which are proteolytic enzymes encoded by the viral genome, are produced by picornaviruses (e.g., coxsackievirus), flaviviruses, retroviruses, adenoviruses, and herpesviruses. These proteases are used for posttranslational modification of translated viral proteins. This process is especially important for the replication of non-segmented RNA viruses (e.g., picornavirus, flavivirus, retrovirus), which translate a single polypeptide that must be subsequently modified into various structural proteins. Other viruses can also utilize host proteases for this process. Inhibitors of viral proteases are used to treat certain viral infections (e.g., simeprevir in hepatitis C, ritonavir in HIV).
Image Description:

In the viral life cycle, the genome of the RNA virus is released into the host cytoplasm after uncoating. In the host cytoplasm, the viral RNA is replicated and, based on its polarity, either directly translated into the amino acid sequence of a polypeptide or transcribed into mRNA through an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Unlike with DNA viruses, the genome of the RNA virus does not enter the nucleus.
questions.hint: Since the cell is denucleated, the virion being studied here is one that is not dependent on the nucleus for replication. The fact that the virion's genetic material can be used to directly translate proteins indicates that the virion has positive-sense RNA as its genetic material.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever for 3 days. She attends kindergarten, where other children have had the same symptoms. Physical examination shows decreased skin turgor. Polymerase chain reaction test (PCR) for rotavirus is positive. Which of the following sets of findings best describe the physical and chemical properties of this virus?



Type of nucleic acid
Strandedness
Envelope
Capsid symmetry



A
RNA
single-stranded
yes
helical


B
DNA
double-stranded
no
icosahedral


C
RNA
single-stranded
no
icosahedral


D
RNA
double-stranded
no
icosahedral


E
DNA
single-stranded
no
icosahedral


F
DNA
double-stranded
yes
icosahedral
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This set of findings describes the characteristics of several virus families, including Orthomyxoviridae (e.g., influenza viruses), Paramyxoviridae (e.g., mumps virus, measles virus, parainfluenza virus), and Coronaviridae (e.g., SARS-associated coronavirus). However, rotavirus possesses different physical and chemical properties.

B) INCORRECT:

This set of findings describes the characteristics of several virus families, including Papillomaviridae (e.g., human papillomavirus), Adenoviridiae (e.g., adenovirus), and Polyomaviridae (e.g., JC virus). However, rotavirus possesses different physical and chemical properties.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of findings describes the characteristics of several virus families, including Picornaviridae (e.g., coxsackievirus, hepatitis A virus), Caliciviridae (e.g., norovirus), and Hepeviridae (e.g., hepatitis E virus). However, rotavirus possesses different physical and chemical properties.

D) CORRECT:

Rotavirus is a non-enveloped, icosahedral, double-stranded RNA virus of the family Reoviridae and is a frequent cause of severe gastroenteritis in young children. Reoviridae are segmented viruses, capable of exchanging single genome segments between different virus strains during co-infection of a single host cell. This process of viral reassortment has the potential to cause antigenic shift and increase the virus's pandemic potential. Moreover, as a non-enveloped virus, rotavirus is resistant to environmental factors including most disinfectants and can survive for several hours on hands and for days on surfaces. The rotavirus vaccine is recommended for infants between 6–32 weeks of age.

E) INCORRECT:

This set of findings describes the characteristics of the Parvoviridae family of viruses (e.g., parvovirus B19). However, rotavirus possesses different physical and chemical properties.

F) INCORRECT:

This set of findings describes the characteristics of Herpesviridae, such as herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1), varicella-zoster virus, and cytomegalovirus. However, rotavirus possesses different physical and chemical properties.
questions.hint: Rotavirus replicates in the cytoplasm of host cells, has a different genome structure than most viruses with the same type of nucleic acid, and is resistant to environmental factors such as heat and disinfectants.

questions.text: A previously healthy 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever and malaise. Yesterday, she developed severe bilateral pain in multiple joints in her hands, wrists, and feet. This morning, she had difficulties getting out of bed because “everything was stiff.” She returned from a trip to Cameroon 1 week ago. She is sexually active with her husband and uses an oral contraceptive. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows tender radiocarpal, metacarpophalangeal, and interphalangeal joints bilaterally in the upper extremities as well as tender tarsophalangeal joints bilaterally in the lower extremities. There is mild cervical lymphadenopathy and a diffuse maculopapular rash on the forearms and shins. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Hemoglobin concentration is 12.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 3,100/mm3, and platelet count is 124,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Exposure to water contaminated with animal urine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disseminated gonococcal infection is caused by systemic dissemination of Neisseria gonorrhea, a gram-negative diplococcus. It often manifests with polyarthralgia in sexually active individuals. However, joint inflammation is usually asymmetric and involves both large and small joints. In addition, patients usually present with tenosynovitis and pustular dermatitis, which are not seen here, and high fever and cervical lymphadenopathy are not associated with disseminated gonococcus.

B) INCORRECT:

Lyme disease is transmitted by Borrelia burgdorferi. It is endemic to the Northeastern and Midwestern US. Acute infection (i.e., early localized Lyme disease) manifests with fever, malaise, and arthralgias, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, patients usually present with a mild transient fever and erythema migrans rather than a high fever and diffuse maculopapular rash.
