In addition, this patient's symmetrical joint inflammation and joint effusion are not expected in Lyme disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is caused by chronic autoimmune T-cell-mediated inflammation of the joint synovium. It manifests with morning stiffness, asymmetric polyarthralgia, and malaise, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, patients with RA develop joint symptoms over months, not days, and fever is usually absent. In addition, RA rarely manifests in patients < 30 years of age.

D) CORRECT:

The Chikungunya virus, which is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries, is primarily transmitted by Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes. In rare cases, it is transmitted during pregnancy or via blood transfusions. Infected patients abruptly develop a high fever (> 39ºC or > 102.2ºF) and malaise after a 3 to 7 day incubation period, usually followed by the development of diffuse polyarthralgia, joint inflammation, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a rash on the limbs and/or trunk. Treatment includes supportive care with anti-inflammatories, antipyretics, and hydration. Symptoms are usually self-limited and resolve within 7 to 10 days, although a minority of patients develop chronic arthralgias.

E) INCORRECT:

Leptospirosis is caused by infection with Leptospirosis interrogans, which is transmitted through exposure to water that is contaminated with animal urine (e.g., via working on farms, swimming in fresh water, or walking barefoot). It manifests with abrupt-onset fever and malaise, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, patients usually also develop headaches and conjunctival suffusion. In addition, leptospirosis is associated with myalgias rather than polyarthralgia and joint inflammation.
questions.hint: This patient's constitutional symptoms (i.e., fever and malaise), diffuse joint inflammation (i.e., symmetric polyarthralgia, joint effusion, and morning stiffness), cervical lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular rash following a recent trip to West Africa (i.e., Cameroon) are highly suggestive of Chikungunya.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of sore throat, myalgia, cough, and loss of taste. The patient's daughter and grandchildren have had similar symptoms for the past week. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The physician obtains a nasopharyngeal specimen. A reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction test (RT-PCR) is performed and confirms infection with an enveloped RNA virus with a helical capsid. Binding to which of the following is responsible for the virulence of this virus?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 binds to the membrane protein angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) expressed in the surface epithelium of the lungs, heart, and other organs. Transmembrane protease serine 2 (TMPRSS2) expressed in respiratory epithelium activates the spike protein, which leads to membrane fusion and uncoating of the viral RNA. Inside the host cells, viral RNA is replicated, and newly constituted viruses are made and released via exocytosis. Symptoms are caused by direct cytopathic effects as well as a dysregulated immune response. The clinical presentation may range from asymptomatic to severe disease with respiratory and multiorgan failure.

See “Receptors used by viruses” table.
Image Description:

Detailed illustration of SARS-CoV-2 cell entry via membrane fusion.

1. The viral spike protein is a homotrimer. Each trimer consists of two different subunits (S1 and S2). As shown in the left zoom box, S1 is located at the top and S2 at the base.

2. The S1 subunit undergoes a hinge-like conformational change to expose the receptor-binding domain (RBD) and binds to the membrane protein ACE2 on host cells.

3. Activation of spike protein (S protein priming): The membrane protein TMPRSS2 acts as a protease. S protein cleavage at the S1/S2 cleavage site leads to cleavage of S1 (including the RBD). The fusion peptide of the S2 subunit is exposed in the cleavage of the S2 site.

4. The fusion peptide of the S2 subunit is inserted in the host cell membrane.

5. Membrane fusion: Conformation change of the S2 subunit (folds together to the side; not depicted here) causes fusion of the viral membrane and host cell membrane. Uncoating of the viral RNA takes place.

B) INCORRECT:

Rhinovirus binds to ICAM-1 (CD54) expressed on respiratory epithelial cells and can result in symptoms similar to those seen here. However, rhinovirus is a nonenveloped RNA virus with an icosahedral capsid.

C) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV), which is an enveloped virus, uses integrins as entry receptors and can cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. However, CMV is a double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid.

D) INCORRECT:

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is an enveloped virus that attaches to the CD4 receptor on host cells (e.g., T helper cells) via glycoprotein 120 (gp120). Acute HIV infection can manifest with symptoms similar to those seen in this scenario, but is unlikely to occur as a family cluster. Moreover, the viral structure of HIV consists of a capsid with a complex, conical shape.

E) INCORRECT:

CD21 is a complement receptor present in mature B lymphocytes and is the site of attachment for the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). EBV is an enveloped virus and can manifest with symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. However, EBV is a DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms suggest COVID-19, which is caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Other enveloped RNA viruses with helical capsids that cause similar symptoms are paramyxovirus, influenza virus, and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department of her local hospital for evaluation of a fever and rash. She reports that she was recently traveling abroad, when an unknown substance was released by a drone over her vacation resort. She flew back to the United States the day after the incident and, for the past 10 days, has been in her home, where she lives with her children and her spouse. Authorities at her destination recently released a statement that the substance released by the drone was likely an infectious pathogen, and they advised anyone who was exposed to quarantine for 3 weeks.
Five days ago, she began to experience flulike symptoms with a fever to 38.8°C, chills, and a headache. Three days ago, she developed clusters of umbilicated vesicles diffusely on both sides of her body, including the palms of the hands. She reports one previous episode of varicella zoster that felt similar but was only on the left side of her chest.
On physical examination, she has a heart rate of 129 beats per minute and a temperature of 38.2°C; other vital signs are normal, and physical examination is notable only for the rash (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is best in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Discharge the patient home with valacyclovir for 14 days
Notify local infectious disease authorities, and transport the patient to an airborne isolation room
Transfer the patient to a tertiary care hospital
Discharge the patient home, and prescribe an antiviral agent to her and her family members
Discharge the patient home with instructions to complete 3 weeks of quarantine and take acetaminophen as needed for her symptoms

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valacyclovir can be used to treat varicella. Although varicella is another possible cause of this patient's rash, it usually features lesions at differing stages of evolution. Discharging the patient home is not advised at this time, as the patient needs to be isolated in an airborne infection isolation room in the hospital and may also benefit from hospital-level care since many patients with smallpox can develop severe illness.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is likely the victim of a bioterrorism attack. A variety of pathogens can quickly spread through a population if released as part of a terrorism attack, but the rash in this case is most concerning for smallpox, an infection caused by the variola virus.

Risk for smallpox in an individual patient can be determined using the diagnostic criteria provided by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Major Diagnostic Criteria for Smallpox:
• Classic smallpox lesions: deep-seated, firm/hard, round, well-circumscribed vesicles or pustules; as they evolve, the lesions may become umbilicated or confluent
• Lesions in the same stage of development (e.g., all are vesicles, or all are pustules) on any one part of the body (e.g., the face, arms)
• Febrile prodrome occurring 1 to 4 days before rash onset and consisting of fever ≥38.3°C and at least one of the following symptoms: prostration, headache, backache, chills, vomiting, severe abdominal pain

Minor Diagnostic Criteria for Smallpox:
• Centrifugal distribution of rash: greatest concentration of lesions on face and distal extremities
• First lesions on the oral mucosa, palate, face, or forearms
• Severity: patient appears toxic or moribund
• Slow rash evolution: lesions evolve from macules to papules to pustules over days (each stage lasts 1 to 2 days)
• Lesions on the palms, soles, or both

Patients who meet all three of the major diagnostic criteria are classified as being at high risk for smallpox and should be treated as probable cases. Patients who have the febrile prodrome plus one of the other major criteria or the febrile prodrome plus at least four minor criteria are classified as being at moderate risk for smallpox.

This patient meets all three major diagnostic criteria and can be considered a probable case. Local health authorities should be notified immediately and will provide further instructions around testing, treatment, and vaccination. Although routine childhood vaccination against smallpox ended in the United States in 1972, smallpox vaccines are still produced and stockpiled to be used in very specific scenarios.

Preventing the spread of smallpox is critical, as smallpox is readily transmitted via droplets, is highly contagious, and carries a high mortality rate. To prevent spread in this case, the patient should be admitted to the hospital immediately and placed in an airborne infection isolation room.

Key learning point: Smallpox has not occurred naturally anywhere in the world since 1977, but if it is used in a bioterrorism attack, exposed individuals should be isolated immediately.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may eventually need a higher level of care, she does not need to be transferred to a tertiary care hospital at this time. She is clinically stable, and transfer could lead to exposure of more individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharging the patient home is not advised at this time, as the patient needs to be isolated in an airborne infection isolation room in the hospital and may also benefit from hospital-level care since many patients with smallpox can develop severe illness.

E) INCORRECT:

Discharging the patient home is not advised at this time, as the patient needs to be isolated in an airborne infection isolation room in the hospital and may also benefit from hospital-level care since many patients with smallpox can develop severe illness.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother, who reports that the girl has had 2 days of fever, runny nose, red eyes, and reduced oral intake. The child has had no vomiting, diarrhea, respiratory distress, or rash. The mother mentions that several other children at her daughter's summer day camp are sick with similar symptoms. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
The girl’s temperature is 38.7°C; her other vital signs are normal. She has bilateral conjunctival injection with a small amount of purulence, nasal congestion, an erythematous posterior oropharynx without exudate or lesions, and shotty cervical lymphadenopathy. Her lungs are clear throughout, and the rest of her examination is unremarkable.
What is the most likely cause of this child’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease (KD) is an acute, vasculitic illness of young children that may manifest with many of the same clinical characteristics as acute adenoviral infection. However, the diagnosis of typical KD requires a fever of 5 or more days plus at least four of the following characteristics: nonexudative conjunctivitis, oropharyngeal mucosal changes, edema or peeling of the extremities, a polymorphous rash, and a large, often unilateral, cervical lymph node. KD is not associated with nasal congestion or otitis media. Although clinicians should always maintain a high index of suspicion for KD, this patient does not meet the diagnostic criteria at this time, and adenovirus infection is the more likely explanation.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus infections can affect the eyes and typically manifest with a unilateral painful red eye. Other symptoms may include pain, watery eye discharge, and blurred vision. This patient’s bilateral presentation as well as fever and upper respiratory symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Moraxella catarrhalis infection typically manifests as otitis media and sinusitis. On rare occasions, it has been associated with conjunctivitis in neonates, but it is not a cause of conjunctivitis in older children.

D) INCORRECT:

Parainfluenza virus infections are a major cause of laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) and other upper and lower respiratory tract infections. They are not associated with conjunctivitis or otitis media.

E) CORRECT:

Adenovirus infection often manifests as a febrile upper respiratory tract infection, which can include symptoms of the common cold, pharyngitis, tonsillitis, conjunctivitis, and (in rare instances) otitis media. Cervical and preauricular lymphadenopathy are common. Most infections are self-limited and can be managed symptomatically.

Adenovirus infection is highly contagious and can occur at any time during the year, but outbreaks are most common in spring and early summer. Community outbreaks have been associated with swimming pools and shared equipment. Proper hand hygiene — as well as contact and droplet precautions when treating hospitalized patients — can help reduce spread of the virus.

Polymerase chain-reaction testing is available for rapid diagnosis of adenovirus infection, but this testing is usually reserved for hospitalized or critically ill patients.

Key learning point: In a child, the most likely cause of an upper respiratory tract infection with pharyngitis, tonsillitis, and exudative conjunctivitis is adenovirus infection.
